headline: Aid to India, new development goals and hurricane Sandy hurts Haiti
text: Should the UK give aid to middle-income countries such as India? The debate has resurfaced as the development secretary, Justine Greening, aims to change the focus to trade not aid. Is she right? As the panel devising the new development goals, Post2015HLP, met in London last week, the UK prime minister, David Cameron, hailed an opportunity to end extreme global poverty. Mark Tran explains the thinking behind the next set of targets and Claire Provost shares the key millennium development goal datasets. Clare Melamed warns that the post-2015 aid agenda is a minefield. Francess Fornah, a midwife from Sierra Leone, says the development framework must be shaped by people with first-hand knowledge. On our Poverty matters blog, Jonathan Glennie argues for a fresh global approach to development, saying a public sector for the whole world could end aid as we know it. Elsewhere on the site The Liberian president, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, in London for the post-2015 high-level panel, responded to claims of nepotism and corruption and reasserted women's role in politics, saying: "We have a story to tell." Jonathan Watts reports from Port-au-Prince on how Haiti has been affected by hurricane Sandy. Our content partner, IRIN, investigates the sobering reality of dealing with dead bodies in disasters. Over the last six years, traffic accidents have killed more people in Mexico than drug wars: how is Mexico improving road safety? Deborah Bonello accompanies police on a night shift in the capital. Coming up Andrew Mitchell will be questioned by MPs on the international development committee over his decision to partially reinstate aid to Rwanda on his last day as development secretary. His successor, Justine Greening, will appear next week. In our November podcast, recorded live at the Development studies association conference, John Vidal and guests debate farming. We are partnering Thomson Reuters Foundation/International Herald Tribune for a conference that brings together 350 women and men to discuss issues impeding women's rights. The Trust Women conference will offer a mix of speeches and debates, and will focus on the clash between culture and law and human rights. Topics under discussion include child marriage, female genital mutilation, acid attacks and "honour" killings, trafficking and domestic slavery. Leading up to the conference, we will be speaking to some of the delegates. We'll also be reporting from the event in London on 4 and 5 December. Find out more or register here. Multimedia Video: Ha-Joon Chang on jobs: "In the end, policies are decided on the street" The Cambridge University economics professor believes poverty reduction and meeting people's basic needs are just one aspect of the development story. In pictures: Fuel smuggling in west Africa Heavily subsidised fuel prices in Nigeria have spawned a large-scale fuel smuggling industry in nearby Benin and Togo. Community Welcome to our new community co-ordinator, @MaeveShearlaw, who joins us from the White Ribbon Alliance. What you said: some of the best reader comments On October's podcast: what does the future hold for UK aid? PeterACMoore wrote:  I'd like to support [the] point about the importance of building a strong civil society to hold leaders to account for their use of domestic as well as international resources.  Passionatedetachment enjoyed part three of our theories of development series on neoliberalism:  Now this is refreshing! Good to see a geographer bringing some critical thinking back into the teaching of development studies.  Annie Kelly reported on how urbanisation in Bangladesh is a double-edged sword for some women. DavidEG wrote:  Gender discrimination is the key to Bangladesh's plight  That awful injustice should be corrected.  Highlights from the blogosphere  Global Voices responds to fiscal reform in the Dominican Republic and finds discontent from business, unions and civil society. DfID blogger Mac-Jordan Degadjor on how mobile technology is helping Ghana decide its future. And the World Bank blog asks, given that only 14% of Tanzanians have electricity, what can be done? And finally  Poverty matters will return in two weeks with another roundup of the latest news and comment. In the meantime, keep up to date on the Global development website.
